title: luck
poem: May the morning rise to greet you
With a softness made of gold,
May the winds that blow around you
May the path beneath your footsteps
The silent hopes, the whispered prayers,
May it gather all your courage
Till you stand in full accord.
Dance toward you all the same.
May the things you thought were endings
Turn to doors you never knew,
Finally break and fall for you.
May your heart stay light and free,
May the world that once felt narrow
And when nights grow long and heavy
And the moon hides from your view,
Come and sit beside you too.
For the road ahead is open,
And the world is bending still;
Your time, your turn, your rising—
So go forward with a bright heart,
Let your spirit see it through—
For luck is not just passing by…

title: Winter Awakening
excerpt: Snow falls like punctuation, pausing the world between one breath and the next.
poem: in a language older than naming.
but with silence, white and waiting,
to make space for what will be.

title: Sunset Letters
excerpt: The sky folds into its own warmth, like a secret being whispered back to fire.
poem: The sky folds into its own warmth,
like a secret being whispered back to fire.
becomes the color everything wants to be.
I carry you in the pause between breaths,
in the way light remembers glass,
If I could write you into permanence,
I would ink you across horizons,
teach the wind to pronounce you gently,
until every sunset learns your name.

title: Urban Solitude
excerpt: The city hums its electric lullaby, a thousand strangers breathing in rhythm.
poem: The city hums its electric lullaby,
a thousand strangers breathing in rhythm,
yet I am the only one awake
in this cathedral of glass and steel.
Neon signs flicker like uncertain prayers,
casting shadows that forget their origins.
I walk these streets like a ghost
Somewhere, a siren sings its urgent song.
But here, in this pocket of stillness,
I am learning the language of alone.

title: Mother's Hands
excerpt: I never noticed when her hands began to age, those instruments of endless giving.
poem: I never noticed when her hands began to age,
weathered by years of folding laundry,
braiding hair, wiping tears, holding on.
Now I see the map of sacrifice
etched in every crease and callus,
written in lines I cannot erase.
One day, I will hold these hands in mine,
and understand the weight of tenderness,
how love can wear the body down

title: Digital Ghosts
excerpt: We are all curators now, archiving moments in pixels and light.
poem: archiving moments in pixels and light,
compressing joy into hearts and thumbs.
what texture of truth slips through
the spaces between ones and zeros.
Perhaps it's not the keeping that matters,
to trust that some things need not be saved.

title: Coffee Shop Chronicles
excerpt: The barista knows my order before I speak, a small intimacy in a city of strangers.
poem: The barista knows my order before I speak,
a small intimacy in a city of strangers.
Steam rises from ceramic like morning prayers,
and for a moment, I belong.
Around me, lives unfold in fragments:
The student underlining textbooks in yellow,
the couple sharing silence like bread,
the freelancer typing what might be a novel
or a manifesto or simply Monday.
We are all here searching for something—
Wi-Fi, warmth, a witness to our being.
The espresso machine hisses its approval,
and we pretend we're not all so alone.

title: The world around us
excerpt: the world around us widens, the moment we let go
poem: Where lost things can be found.
To dreams we never speak of,
To hopes we hold so near.
With clouds that drift and fade,
In ways both sharp and kind—
It shows us how the flowers
How storms may break the branches
It knows the weight of longing,
A place for each of us to fall.
The doors we used to close.
For in the world around us,
We all can find our place.
